title: How to Clean a Travel Backpack

steps.headline: Read the manufacturer’s cleaning instructions first.
steps.description: Spot cleaning your backpack with a damp cloth can safely be done on any backpack, regardless of its material. However, not all backpacks are designed to be cleaned by submerging them in water or applying detergents or stain removers. Follow the guidance of the cleaning instructions to prevent damage to your backpack. If your backpack is still under warranty, it is especially important to follow the manufacturer’s cleaning instructions so you do not void that warranty. Some backpacks may be covered in a waterproofing material that can be damaged if submerged in water or washed with regular detergent.

steps.headline: Remove everything from inside the backpack and shake out the dirt.
steps.description: Take absolutely everything out from inside the backpack. Check each and every compartment and pocket. Once empty, hold your backpack upside down and shake out loose crumbs and dirt. If there’s dirt stuck in the creases of your backpack, use a vacuum to remove as much of that dirt as possible before proceeding. You can also try using a makeup brush to loosen dirt stuck in the corners or edges of the inside of your backpack. If your backpack has a removable metal frame, take that out before proceeding.

steps.headline: Apply a stain remover and allow it to sit for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Use a stain remover on any stains you find on the inside or outside of your backpack. Follow the instructions on the stain remover to determine how to apply the stain remover and how long it should sit on the fabric before proceeding. Use a toothbrush or a cloth to scrub the stain remover into the stain.

steps.headline: Fill a sink with warm water and mild non-detergent soap.
steps.description: Find a sink or a bucket that’s large enough to fit your entire backpack. If necessary, you can use your bathtub. Fill that sink, bucket, or tub with warm water and add a small amount of mild non-detergent soap. Use your hand to mix the soap into the water. Non-detergent soap is made from natural items (i.e., fats and oils from plants and animals) as opposed to synthetic chemicals. In general, non-detergent soaps are gentler on fabrics and won’t damage any protective coatings it has. You can also purchase soap specifically designed to clean backpacks if you want to be extra careful.

steps.headline: Submerge your backpack in the sink and scrub gently.
steps.description: Put your backpack in the sink, bucket, or tub and make sure it’s completely submerged under the water. Use a cloth to wash the inside and outside of your backpack. Use a soft brush or a toothbrush to scrub any really dirty areas or stains. Avoid using hot water, as it may make the colours on your backpack’s fabric run. Do not use bleach or fabric softener to hand wash your backpack. Both items may ruin the fabric or its protective coating.

steps.headline: Refill the sink with clean cool water for rinsing.
steps.description: Take your backpack out of the sink, bucket, or tub and empty the soapy water. Refill the sink, bucket, or tub with clean, cool water. If you have a double laundry sink or two buckets, you can have the second sink or bucket ready with cool water. Make sure you rinse all the soap out of the sink, bucket, or tub before refilling it with clean water.

steps.headline: Place your backpack in the clean water and thoroughly rinse away the soap.
steps.description: Submerge your backpack in the clean water and use a clean cloth or your hand to wipe the soap off the fabric. Make sure to rinse all areas of the outside and inside of your backpack. You may need to turn your backpack inside out to rinse the inside parts. If you’re using a sink or a tub, drain the water while your backpack is still inside. Use the faucet to rinse any leftover soap out of your backpack.

steps.headline: Allow your backpack to air dry lying down or hanging upside down.
steps.description: Take the backpack out of the sink, bucket, or tub and wring it as best you can. You can also use a dry towel to try to soak up as much excess water as you can, especially inside the various compartments. Lay the bag flat on another dry towel or hang it upside down to air dry. Do not use or store your backpack until it is totally and completely dry. Do not put your backpack in the dryer. The heat will ruin the fabric and its protective coating.

steps.headline: Review the manufacturer’s cleaning instructions thoroughly.
steps.description: Do not put your backpack in a washing machine unless the manufacturer’s cleaning instructions indicate it’s okay. If your backpack has any leather on it, even leather trim, do not put it in a washing machine. If your backpack has decals, jewels, or other items glued or sewn onto the outside, it should probably be hand washed to ensure those items aren’t damaged. Most child backpacks can likely be placed in the washing machine. Cleaning your backpack in a washing machine may void the warranty.

steps.headline: Take everything out of the backpack and leave all of the pockets open.
steps.description:
Open every single pocket and compartment of your backpack and take every item out. Also, remove any detachable items like straps or compartments. Hold your backpack upside down and shake out any loose dirt or debris. Use a vacuum to remove dirt that’s hidden in hard-to-reach areas of the inside of your backpack
You can also use a clean make-up brush to loosen dirt from the creases or edges of inside compartments.

steps.headline: Allow a stain remover to soak into major stains for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Use a gentle stain remover on any major stains on both the inside and outside of your backpack. Read and follow the instructions for the stain remover for the specific steps. Leave the stain remover on your backpack for at least 30 minutes. Use a cloth or a toothbrush to scrub at the various stains you find.

steps.headline: Put your backpack inside a laundry bag or pillowcase for protection.
steps.description: Use a large laundry bag, mesh bag, or pillowcase to protect your backpack while it’s in the washing machine. This will help ensure that the backpack doesn’t get snagged on the agitator or isn’t twisted and stretched out of shape. It will also prevent any missed items from inside the backpack from getting loose. You can purchase a laundry bag at a department store or online. If you opt to use a pillowcase, make sure to use one that is the same colour as your backpack. That way, if the colours of either item run, they won’t ruin the other item.

steps.headline: Use the gentle cycle, mild non-detergent soap, and cold water.
steps.description: Place your protected backpack inside the washing machine. For really large backpacks, you likely won’t be able to add any other items to the load. For smaller backpacks, you can include other items in the load. Set the washing machine to the gentle or delicate cycle with cold water and use only non-detergent soap. Do not use hot water to wash your backpack, as it may cause the colours to run. If you decide to wash other items with your backpack, make sure they’re of similar colours so nothing is ruined if the colours run. You can find non-detergent soap at a grocery store or online.

steps.headline: Take your backpack out of the laundry bag and let it air dry.
steps.description: Once the washing machine is finished, take your backpack out and remove it from the laundry bag or pillowcase. Place your backpack on a dry towel or hang it upside down to air dry. If you’re able to hang it outside, it may dry faster. You can hang the laundry bag or pillowcase to dry as well, or you can put it into the dryer with another load. Do not put your backpack in the dryer, the heat will ruin the fabric and its protective coating.

steps.headline: Wipe off and shake out your backpack on a weekly basis.
steps.description: Use a clean cloth and warm water to wipe away any dirt from the outside of your backpack. Shake out your backpack regularly to remove all debris and crumbs. Use a vacuum to remove hard-to-reach dirt if necessary. The more often you wipe down your backpack, the easier it’ll be to clean more thorough when needed. Cleaning your backpack weekly can also help prevent stains.

steps.headline: Remove wet or damp items as soon as possible.
steps.description: Don’t allow wet, damp, or sweaty items to sit inside your backpack for a long period of time. Remove those items every night, if possible, or immediately when you get home from a hiking trip. Dampness can cause mould to form, which can be much harder to remove and clean.

steps.headline: Take leftover food out of your backpack every day.
steps.description: Take all the leftover food out of your backpack as soon as possible. Hold your empty backpack upside down and shake out any crumbs that may have built-up inside your backpack. Use your vacuum to remove crumbs that have fallen into hard-to-reach areas. Food can be the cause of nasty smells if not removed immediately. Those smells may be harder to remove if they’ve been absorbed into the fabric.

steps.headline: Use baking soda to remove odours from the inside of your backpack.
steps.description: Sprinkle baking soda into all the compartments of your backpack every couple of weeks and allow it to sit overnight. Hold your backpack upside down to shake out the baking soda the next day, or use a vacuum to remove all the baking soda. Spray the inside of your backpack with white vinegar. Allow the vinegar to dry—don’t rinse or wipe it away. Alternatively, spray newspaper with water mixed with a tiny amount of vanilla extract. Crumble up the newspaper and put it inside your backpack for a weekend, then remove. You can also place a new dryer sheet inside the main compartments of your backpack to keep it smelling nice.

steps.headline: Use a backpack cover when it’s raining or muddy.
steps.description: To prevent stains and dampness from invading your backpack, purchase and use a rain cover. A rain cover is simply a loose piece of material, usually with elastic around the edges, that goes over the top of your backpack in bad weather. The rain cover is waterproof and will prevent water from soaking into your backpack’s fabric and inside the backpack itself. Some backpacks come with built-in rain covers that usually pull out of a compartment on the bottom of the backpack. Rain covers can be purchased at sporting goods stores or online.

steps.headline: Pack your backpack using dry bags or packing cubes.
steps.description: Rather than throwing everything directly into your backpack, especially for overnight trips, use dry bags or packing cubes instead. Not only will dry bags and packing cubes keep the inside of your backpack clean, but they can also help organize your clothes and gear, making things easier to find when needed. Dry bags and packing cubes can be purchased at sporting goods stores and online. Dry bags are especially useful for storing wet or damp items.
